incidents.name: Capacity issues in IAD, BOS, EWR

incident_updates.body: This incident has been resolved.
We've freed up some capacity in the affected regions and are starting to see recovery in metrics and app logs services.

We are investigating regional capacity issues in `iad`, `bos`, and `ewr`. Existing applications in these regions may experience reduced performance or elevated latency, and new deployments may fail. We are working on balancing resources to free up capacity.
This issue is also impacting metrics and log ingestion services, so you may see some delay in metrics and app logs.
This incident has been resolved.
We have mitigated the issues and deploys should now be working as expected
The issue has been identified and a fix is being implemented.
We are continuing to work on a fix. Updates to follow.
We have identified the issue and are working on a fix. In the meantime, you can add `--depot=false` to your flyctl deploy command to opt out of using depot builders.
We are investigating an issue with Depot builders failing.

components.name: Deployments
components.description: flyctl and GitHub Action app deployments

incident_updates.body: This incident is now resolved.
After reverting the suspect changes, our metrics indicate service recovery.  The Machines API is now operating normally. We are monitoring for any lingering issues.
We've identified the problematic change and are performing a rollback to restore service.

Fly API operations are currently slow or failing, we're investigating the cause.

This will affect most operations that rely in the machines API, including starting Fly builders, deploying, creating/destroying machines, querying machine or volume data via the API.

Existing, running apps and machines are not affected and continue to serve normally.
This incident has been resolved.
Machines deployed in EZE have lost IPv6 connectivity due to an upstream issue. We are actively working with our upstream provider to get this resolved.
This incident has been resolved.

We have applied a fix and are now seeing logs flow through to user's fly-metrics dashboards. 

We are containing to monitor the dashboard to ensure recovery.

We are investigating reports of missing logs in customer's fly-metrics dashboards. 

Only log search in the fly-metrics hosted Grafana instance is impacted. Checking logs using `flyctl logs`, the live logs page in the dashboard, or using a Fly-Log-Shipper app continues to work as expected.
This incident has been resolved.
The issue has been identified and we are working on a fix.
We are currently investigating increased response times from the Machines API.
Between 18:35-19:30 UTC, a routing issue prevented application traffic from reaching machines in the JNB region. The issue has now been resolved.
The maintenance has been completed.

We are continuing to investigate this issue.  Networking to some customer apps, Fly API operations, and access to Fly.io Dashboard pages continues to be impacted.
We're currently investigating an outage based on alerts and customer reports. This affects the Fly dashboard and some customer apps, as well as the API.
The issue affecting Machine leases for API and CLI users is now resolved. All systems are back to normal.

We have identified the issue affecting Machine leases, which was impacting both Machines API and Fly CLI users. The problem has now been mitigated, and services are returning to normal. 
We will continue to monitor the situation to ensure full stability.
We are currently investigating an issue whereby some users may be experiencing trouble related to Machine leases. This affects Machines API users as well Fly CLI users.
This incident has been resolved.

A fix is being deployed slowly across the fleet. While a fix is being deployed to a host server, API operations on the Fly Machines on that server may fail. Fly Machines themselves will continue to function normally.

Users may see higher rates of 504 and 408 HTTP errors when accessing the Fly Platform API. These may occur particularly with the deploy, scale, and destroy commands. These errors will only occur in relation to specific Fly Machines. Recommended work arounds include ignoring affected Machines during a deploy with --exclude-machines, or destroying an affected Machine with fly m destroy. The problem only involves API operations; Fly Machines themselves function normally.
We have deployed the fix and confirmed GitHub OAuth logins are operational again.
We have identified the issue and working to deploy a fix.

incidents.name: Machines API incorrectly returning 200 instead of 201

incident_updates.body: A change was deployed around tracking status codes but it incorrectly handled the case where a 201 was written and then later a 200 would overwrite it. The change has been reverted back to the original/correct behavior.
GraphQL API and Dashboard are fully operational again.
We are still seeing sporadic errors and we are continuing to investigate.
GraphQL-based operations appear to be succeeding and the Dashboard is available. We are continuing to monitor for further issues.
A fix has been rolled out and we are currently monitoring.
An initial fix is being tested and we are looking to roll it out shortly.

We have identified an issue with our GraphQL API which many Fly.io services interact with. The Dashboard, Flyctl deployments and the Machines API are currently affected. Most users will will experience 503 errors when deploying from flyctl or GitHub Actions at this time.
We are continuing to investigate this issue. Users may experience intermittent 503 errors when trying to access the Dashboard or interact with services that rely on the GraphQL API (i.e Flyctl)
We are currently investigating an issue with the Fly.io dashboard where users are unable to log in

incidents.name: Upstash Redis Connectivity issues in IAD

incident_updates.body: This issue has been resolved.
The host has been brought back online and work is being done to restore the Upstash Redis Cluster in IAD.

Some existing Upstash Redis databases in the IAD region are still experiencing connection issues. We are continuing to work on restoring the impacted host to restore these. 
The ability to create new Upstash Redis databases in the IAD has been restored. Newly created databases are not impacted by the current issue.

We have identified the cause of the issues to a host hardware failure that is impacting the Upstash Redis cluster. We are working to restore the failed hardware.

Upstash Redis Databases with primaries in regions other than IAD are not impacted.
We are continuing to investigate this issue.
We are investigating customer issues connecting to Upstash Redis primaries in the IAD region

affected_components.name: Regional Availability - GRU - São Paulo, Brazil

incident_updates.body:
This incident has been resolved. 

Some of our edges received incorrect state data for a small number of apps that used the bluegreen deploy strategy. This resulted in 502 errors when attempting to reach those apps. We identified approximately 36 apps that were impacted, including the Fly.io homepage and dashboard.

A small number of customer apps may still be seeing 502 errors due to stale state information. We are working to address this. For any apps still experiencing the error, re-deploying with `fly deploy` will correct the state information and resolve the errors.
A full fix has been implemented and we continue to monitor platform status. Impacted customer apps should be operational shortly, if they are not already.

A fix has been deployed and The Fly.io homepage, dashboard, API and metrics pages are back online and operational. A small number of customer apps may still be seeing elevated 502 errors. We are working to address this currently.
We have identified the cause of the issue and are working on a fix.
We are currently investigating elevated rates of 502 errors when accessing applications hosted on Fly.io, including the Fly.io homepage, dashboard, and fly-metrics pages.

incident_updates.body: Our billing provider has resolved their incident and our systems confirm we are resolved as well.
Our billing provider has resolved their incident and our systems confirm we are resolved as well.
We are continuing to work on a fix for this issue.

Due to an upstream outage, our billing system is experiencing a partial outage. Invoices may fail to load and/or be missing lines, and credits (including purchased credits) may fail to load.If you previously purchased credits and your credit balance is now showing $0.00, please be aware that this is a UI outage only - your credit balance will show the correct figure once the outage is resolved.

incidents.name: Builders are having issues being created in gru region

incident_updates.body: We have deployed a fix to the issue.

We have identified the issue and are actively working on a fix. In the meantime, you may work around by destroying your remote builder app and recreating it in another region nearby, e.g Rio de Janeiro (gig).

Identify the name of your builder app (prefixed with "fly-builder-"):
fly apps list

Destroy the builder:
fly apps destroy <builder-app-name>

Redeploy with a builder app in another region:
FLY_REMOTE_BUILDER_REGION=gig fly deploy
We are currently investigating this issue

incidents.name: Packet loss, Machines API and deployment errors in Singapore

incident_updates.body: Network metrics in SIN have returned to baseline following routing configuration updates. The issues were caused by network faults experienced by some of our upstream providers.
We have updated regional routing configuration to circumvent network faults experienced by some of our upstream providers and are continuing to monitor.
We're investigating reports of deployment failures and machines API timeouts in the `sin` region, as well as elevated packet loss which might impact deployed applications.
